content.text: Calculate the value of \(C\)
Calculate the uncertainty in \(C\)
uncertainty = .........\(\mathsf{Ns}\mathsf{m}^{-2}\)
State the value of \(C\) and its uncertainty to the appropriate number of significant figures
The volume \(V\) of liquid flowing in time \(t\) through a pipe of radius \(r\) is given by the equation
where \(P\) is the pressure difference between the ends of the pipe of length \(l\) , and \(C\) depends on the frictional effects of the liquid
An experiment is performed to determine \(C\) .The measurements made are shown in Fig. 1.1
Calculate the speed of the ball as it hits the ground
Show that the time taken for the ball to reach the ground is 0.47 s
A ball is thrown vertically down towards the ground and rebounds as illustrated in Fig. 2.1

As the ball passes A, it has a speed of \(8.4 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The height of A is \(5.0 \text{m}\) above the ground. The ball hits the ground and rebounds to B. Assume that air resistance is negligible

The ball rebounds vertically with a speed of \(4.2 \text{m s}^{-1}\) as it leaves the ground. The time the ball is in contact with the ground is \(20 \text{ms}\). The ball rebounds to a maximum height \(h\)

The ball passes A at time \(t = 0\). On Fig. 2.2, plot a graph to show the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the ball. Continue the graph until the ball has rebounded from the ground and reaches B
For this motion, calculate the change in
1. kinetic energy,
change in kinetic energy = .........J
2. gravitational potential energy
change in potential energy = .........J
State and explain the total change in energy of the ball for this motion
The ball has a mass of \(0.050 \text{kg}\). It moves from A and reaches B after rebounding
State Newton's first law
With reference to the motion of the log, discuss whether the log is in equilibrium
Calculate the tension in the wire
tension = .........N
State and explain whether the gain in the potential energy per unit time of the log is equal to the output power of the motor
A log of mass \(450 \text{kg}\) is pulled up a slope by a wire attached to a motor, as shown in Fig. 3.1
The angle that the slope makes with the horizontal is \(12^{\circ}\). The frictional force acting on the log is \(650 \text{N}\). The log travels with constant velocity
The switch S is open. Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) across XY
The switch S is closed. The resistance of the LDR is 4.0 kΩ. Calculate the current in the ammeter
current = .........A
the ammeter reading,
the p.d. across XY
The switch S remains closed. The intensity of the light on the LDR is increased. State and explain the change to
A battery of electromotive force \(12\mathrm{V}\) and negligible internal resistance is connected to two resistors and a light-dependent resistor (LDR), as shown in Fig. 4.1
An ammeter is connected in series with the battery. The LDR and switch S are connected across the points XY
Define the Young modulus
State two quantities, other than the gradient of the graph in Fig. 5.1, that are required in order to determine the Young modulus of steel
Describe how the quantities you listed in (i) may be measured
A load of \(3.0 \text{N}\) is applied to the wire. Use Fig. 5.1 to calculate the energy stored in the wire
energy = .........J
A load \(F\) is suspended from a fixed point by a steel wire. The variation with extension \(x\) of \(F\) for the wire is shown in Fig. 5.1

A copper wire has the same original dimensions as the steel wire. The Young modulus for steel is \(2.2 \times 10^{11} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\) and for copper is \(1.1 \times 10^{11} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\)
On Fig. 5.1, sketch the variation with \(x\) of \(F\) for the copper wire for extensions up to \(0.25 \text{mm}\). The copper wire is not extended beyond its limit of proportionality.
Use the principle of superposition to explain the formation of a stationary wave
Describe an experiment to determine the wavelength of sound in air using stationary waves. Include a diagram of the apparatus in your answer
On the \(x\)-axis of Fig. 6.1, indicate the positions of all the nodes and antinodes of the stationary wave. Label the nodes \(\mathbf{N}\) and the antinodes \(\mathbf{A}\).
The speed of sound in air is \(340 \text{m s}^{-1}\)
Use Fig. 6.1 to determine the frequency of the sound wave
frequency = .........Hz
The variation with distance \(x\) of the intensity \(I\) of a stationary sound wave is shown in Fig. 6.1
\(I\) / arbitrary units
A nuclear reaction occurs when a uranium-235 nucleus absorbs a neutron. The reaction may be represented by the equation:
State the number represented by the letter
W
X
Y
Z
The sum of the masses on the left-hand side of the equation in (a) is not the same as the sum of the masses on the right-hand side
Explain why mass seems not to be conserved
